sub_title: Historian - Lecturer and Marie Skłodowska-Curie Recipient, Leiden University
summary:
Dr Bram van Leuveren (he/they) is a cultural historian of early modern Europe and works as Marie Skłodowska-Curie Individual Fellow at Leiden University, The Netherlands. Bram researches the salient role of the performing arts and ceremonial protocol in supporting diplomatic relations between the Low Countries and its most important European associates in the late sixteenth to seventeenth centuries, notably France and Great Britain. Bram's research is transnational, comparative, and interdisciplinary in scope. It particularly focuses on questions of cultural exchange, translation, identity, and spectatorship.

Bram's first monograph, 𝘌𝘢𝘳𝘭𝘺 𝘔𝘰𝘥𝘦𝘳𝘯 𝘋𝘪𝘱𝘭𝘰𝘮𝘢𝘤𝘺 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘍𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘩 𝘍𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘷𝘢𝘭 𝘊𝘶𝘭𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦, 1572-1615, is based on his/their doctoral research at the University of St Andrews, United Kingdom, will appear in the 'Rulers & Elites' series of Brill on 31 August 2023: <https://brill.com/display/title/58251?rskey=iAXp6j&result=4>. It is the first book-length study court and civic festivals of the late Valois and early Bourbon rulers from a pan-European perspective. Bram has lectured art and political history in the early modern period at the University of St Andrews, Leiden University, and Groningen University, the Netherlands.

In 2021, the European Commission awarded Bram a highly competitive Marie Skłodowska-Curie Individual Fellow in recognition of his/their research and leadership skills as a historian. The fellowship sponsors Bram's two-year research project 'Public Diplomacy in Early Modern Europe: Theatrical Entertainments for the State Journeys of English and French Royals into the Low Countries, 1577-1642' at Leiden University Centre for the Arts in Society (LUCAS): <https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/101029762>. Bram has also been a recipient of a prestigious Maddock Research Fellowship from Marsh's Library, Dublin, in October 2019, which enabled him/them to study the library's remarkable collection of 17th-century pamphlets on nuptial diplomacy.

Besides conducting his/their individual EU-sponsored research, Bram has worked on various research teams. Most notably, in 2019-2020, Bram was hired for his/their expertise in digital humanities research to develop an online open-access database, entitled 'Theatre in Saint-Domingue, 1764-1791: Plays, Ballets and Operas', within a large research team of historians, translators, and software engineers headed by Julia Prest (University of St Andrews). The database can be accessed at <https://www.theatreinsaintdomingue.org/>.

profile_positions.description:
•	Highly competitive individual fellowship awarded by the European Commission in recognition of 
        my academic research and leadership skills, as part of their Horizon 2020 research and innovation 
        funding programme.
•	Grant amount awarded: €175572.48.
•	Sponsors my individual two-year research project ‘Public Diplomacy in Early Modern Europe: 
        Theatrical Entertainments for the State Journeys of English and French Royals into the Low 
        Countries, 1577-1642’ (PUBLICDIPLO, 2021-2023, grant agreement number: 101029762). 

One way for governments to conduct foreign policy and promote national interests is through direct outreach and communication with the population of a foreign country. This is called public diplomacy. Historians such as Helmer Helmers and William T. Rossiter have shown that printed media were already widely used for public diplomacy by European governments and their diplomats in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. However, the role that pageantry, such as ballets, firework dramas, and mock tournaments, played in early modern foreign relations is often overlooked. Knowledge of this tradition helps to increase historical awareness about ideas and practices of diplomatic communication prior to the foundation of the European Union. This EU-funded project will explore the diplomatic function and reception of early modern pageantry. The focus will be on the theatrical entertainments staged for the state journeys of the English and French monarchy into the Low Countries between 1577 and 1642.
profile_positions.title: Marie Skłodowska-Curie Fellow

company.name: The Society for Court Studies - European Branch Committee

profile_positions.company: The Society for Court Studies - European Branch Committee
profile_positions.description:
•	Collaborating with peers on organising series of virtual talks on court history (from antiquity until 
        present times), hands-on workshops for early career researchers on relevant research-skills, 
        distributing information on relevant academic events, projects, and publications, and maintaining 
        the branch’s network of court historians across the globe.
profile_positions.title: Board Member

company.name: The International Network for Early Modern Festival Study

profile_positions.company: The International Network for Early Modern Festival Study
profile_positions.description:
•	Distributing information on academic events, projects, and publications related to the international 
        study of early modern festivals, as well as facilitating collaboration and dialogue between members of 
        the network.
profile_positions.title: Network Coordinator

profile_positions.description:
•	Designed, taught, and convened my own Research Master module based on my research on early 
        modern diplomacy and arts: ‘Political Uses of Festival Culture in Early Modern and Contemporary 
        Culture’.
o	5 ECTS.
o	1 group of 15 students.
o	Weekly online lectures and seminars and marking and designing of coursework.
o	Thesis supervision.

•	Bachelor module taught and convened: ‘Narrative Across Media’, which focused on practices of 
        storytelling across various art media, both in the early modern period and the present.
o	10 ECTS.
o	2 groups of 20 students each.
o	Weekly online lectures and seminars and marking and designing of coursework and exams.

•	Bachelor module taught and convened: ‘Theatre II: History’, which focused on developments in 
        early- to mid-20th-century political theatre, including Artaud, Brecht, and the Living Theatre.
o	10 ECTS.
o	3 groups of 20 students each.
o	Weekly online lectures and seminars and marking of coursework and exams.

•	Bachelor module taught, convened, and co-designed: ‘Minority Representations in Arts, Culture and 
        Media’, which concentrated on the ethics and aesthetics of representing minority cultures in 
        contemporary arts, culture, and media.
o	10 ECTS.
o	3 groups of 20 students each.
o	Weekly online seminars and marking and designing of coursework and exams.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer in Arts, Culture and Media Studies

profile_positions.description:
•	Bachelor module taught and convened: ‘European Art and Architecture in the Seventeenth and 
        Eighteenth Century’, which introduced students to key developments in the field, while also 
        considering Europe’s exchanges with the Islamic world, especially the Ottoman Empire.
o	20 Scotland Credits = 10 ECTS. 
o	5 groups of 10 students each.
o	Weekly seminars, office hours, and marking of coursework and exams.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer in Art History

profile_positions.description:
•	Worked as a digital humanities researcher within a large research team of historians, software 
        engineers, and translators on an online open-access database of theatre and performance records 
        in the early modern French colony of Saint-Domingue (now Haiti) between 1764 and 1791 (see 
        https://www.theatreinsaintdomingue.org/).
•	Responsibilities included mining and analysing advertisements for public performances as 
        published in weekly Saint-Dominguan newspapers and updating the website’s database, using 
        the software MySQL.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Research Assistant

profile_positions.description:
•	Studied the remarkable collection of printed French-language pamphlets on the Habsburg-Bourbon 
        double marriages of 1612-1615 held at Marsh’s Library. The pamphlets were commissioned by the 
        French crown, its adversaries, as well as English and Spanish ambassadors.
profile_positions.title: Maddock Research Fellow

profile_positions.description:
•	Bachelor module taught and convened: ‘The Early Modern Western World, c. 1450-c. 1770’, which 
        focused on key episodes and developments from Europe’s early modern history, including the 
        (Counter-)Reformation, the Wars of Religion, state building, absolutism, and the Enlightenment. 
o	20 Scotland Credits = 10 ECTS.
o	4 groups of 6 students each.
o	Weekly seminars, office hours, designing curriculum, and setting and marking of coursework and 
        exams.

•	Bachelor module taught and convened: ‘History as a Discipline: Developments and Key Concepts’, 
        which introduced main concepts, trends and developments in 19th- to 21st-century historiography, 
        including cultural and intellectual history, microhistory, and gender and postcolonial studies.  
o	20 Scotland Credits = 10 ECTS.
o	4 groups of 6 students each.
o	Weekly seminars, office hours, and setting and marking of coursework and exams.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer in Early Modern History

profile_positions.description: I taught the 1st-year undergraduate module ‘The Nineteenth-Century Novel of Adultery’. My responsibilities involved weekly seminar teaching, office hours, and marking of coursework and exams.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer in Comparative Literature

profile_positions.description:
•	Co-founded ‘Byre World’, a biweekly series of outreach events at a local theatre in St Andrews, with 
        colleagues at the School of Modern Languages. The series seeks to make the study of modern 
         foreign language accessible to a wide audience of academics, students, and locals. 
•	‘Byre World’ continues to attract more than 1,000 attendees per year.
profile_positions.title: Co-Founder Byre World (Outreach)

profile_positions.description:
•	Liaised with book reviewers of the journal (owned by Oxford University Press), compiled lists of 
        received books, sent off requested books, and processed incoming reviews for publication.
profile_positions.title: Book Reviews Administrator for Forum for Modern Language Studies

profile_positions.description: My participation in this interdisciplinary project on the social and ethical effects of reflecting on literary fiction, led by Prof. Liesbeth Korthals Altes, was funded by the Dutch Research Council (NWO). My responsibilities included analysing academic literature and assisting Prof. Korthals Altes with the publication of her monograph Ethos and Narrative Interpretation: The Negotiation of Values in Fiction (Lincoln and London: University of Nebraska Press, 2014).
profile_positions.title: Academy Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: I co-founded the academic peer-reviewed journal for Honours College students from the University of Groningen. My editorial responsibilities included reviewing and revising submitted articles in the fields of history and arts, culture and media, and informing the editorial board about scholarly trends and developments.
profile_positions.title: Co-Founder and Editor of Honours Review

profile_positions.description: I co-taught the 3rd-year undergraduate module ‘Theatre in Practice’ with Dr Danae Theodoridou. The module focussed on key theories in performance studies, particularly in relation to emotion and affect, the body, and Derridean deconstruction. My responsibilities involved weekly seminar teaching, marking of coursework and exams, and supervising a practice-based research project of 4 students.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Tutor in Theatre Studies
